Minor follow-up on Zulip. Mainly of interest to <@UC2A2ARPT>. I've been missing Zulip's channel view for a couple of months now. Turns out they put it into the context menu. And you get out of it if you breathe on the thing wrong. They basically took the essence of Zulip and completely fucked it up. If I wanted per-topic views I could go use, like, phpBB.

There is no way around it. People that talk together should run their own platform and potentially write their own platform. The medium is the message.

text:
I just noticed people on the Concatenative Discord doing something really cool. It being Discord, you can group channels. So there's a group called Labs, and under it anyone can create a channel for themselves, like #clarity-lab or #capitals-cool-corner.

It's like a per-person <#C03RR0W5DGC|devlog-together>, but the goal is subtly different <https://akkartik.name/archives/foc/administrivia/1659038630.439149.html|if I look back at the genesis of that channel>. The fact that there's no aggregation means you can basically assume nobody will see what you post there. But you can go back and link to something if it becomes relevant. This feels like it better captures the Christopher-Alexander ethos of #garage-door-open that we also alluded to in that thread.

In 2024 I spent a certain amount of effort creating a devlog for myself on my own site. But it still feels like a site and so something more heavy. A chat might work better as a lab notebook. I'm not sure chat would work for me, it doesn't feel natural. But perhaps this is something to think about in our Next Forum™.

text: Right now I'm kinda thinking of the opposite of that. Aggregating things nudges people to follow them. A long flat list of feeds nudges people to ignore them. Like home workshops but with hyperlinks.

text:
Oh, my home Discord also uses this style of 'lab notebook' channel. They aren't explicitly per-person, but our conversational norm is to not change topics in one channel too quickly. So in a channel that gets one post per week, as opposed to two posts per day, the effect is that it has an owner. Who sometimes changes.

I feel compelled to argue in favor of this state of fluidity (i.e. no fixed owner) because, in part, I still haven't got Medium to click for me. Well, every Medium is its own newsletter, for a start. But Medium posts lack the equivalent of WordPress-style ping-backs. This would mean I can't notify someone I'm _directly responding to_ without also sliding into their comments. Is that really the norm on Medium?

Ultimately, I'm just not going to effort-post if it isn't an organic part of some conversation, even if it's a very slow and drawn-out conversation. Therefore, the critical piece here is not the forum's precise structure of aggregation. It is the pingback whenever someone either replies (inside of the thread), or loudly replies (in the aggregated feed, if applicable).
